title: What is the historical context of SPQR? - Quora

response.answer_text: Letters SPQR can be seen on many monuments, buildings and banners. They mean Senatus Populusque Romanus, meaning “Roman Senate and People”. These words were a symbol of Roman identity and official name of the Roman Empire. Abbreviation SPQR, until the eagle’s image became popular, served as the state emblem. It is also possible that the SPQR shortcut was also tattooed on the Roman legionaries’ arms. SPQR appeared on the coins of the period of the Republic, on the banners of the legions and monuments.  read more: SPQR - what do these letters mean? « IMPERIUM ROMANUM

What did “spor” [sic] mean in ancient Rome? I suspect that you misread SPQR, and have edited the question appropriately. SPQR abbreviates the phrase Senatus PopulusQue Romanus, meaning “The Senate and the Roman People”. In the time of the Republic, these two parts, the Senate and the common populace represented by their elected representatives the Tribunes (who could in theory veto, that is forbid, any action ordained by the Senate) made up the force behind any action taken by the state. In the Empire, it was a rubber stamp on the decisions of the Emperor.
